sentence.text: ﻿Patients 1 and 2 were dizygotic twins (male and female) from the first pregnancy of a healthy consanguineous couple (first cousins once removed, e.g., fourth degree of consanguinity).
The couple had conceived following in vitro fertilization.
Early pregnancy was uneventful and the results of ultrasound (US) examination at gestational age (GA) of 14 weeks had been reported to be a normal twin pregnancy.

US at our hospital at GA 20 + 6 demonstrated a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy with different gender and signs of skeletal dysplasia in both fetuses including short stature, micromelia, absent ossification of skull and of vertebral bodies, a narrow thorax with a circumference corresponding to 2.5th centile for GA.
Fetal and postnatal measurements are summarized in Table I.
Three-dimensional US demonstrated mid-facial hypoplasia, micromelia, brachydactyly, and a virtually non-mineralized spine (Fig. 1A).
A diagnosis of lethal skeletal dysplasia, possibly achondrogenesis type 1, was suggested.
The mother decided to continue the pregnancy.
At GA 27 + 3, she developed respiratory difficulties and abdominal pain due to polyhydramnios.
The delivery was induced, and both fetuses were stillborn at GA 27 + 3.

Postpartum examination in both demonstrated flat faces, protruding eyes, small noses with anteverted nares, tilted mouths, protruding tongues, and short stature with a short trunk and neck, short limbs with abundant soft tissue, abnormally positioned feet, and short fingers and toes (Fig. 2A–C).
The autopsy was denied.
Postnatal radiography showed brachycephaly with deficient mineralization of the calvaria.
The vertebral bodies and sacrum were unossified.
In contrast, the pedicles were ossified in the cervical, thoracic and upper lumbar spine.
The thorax was hypoplastic.
Thirteen pairs of markedly short and beaded ribs with flared and spurred ends were noted.
The scapulae had a stellate appearance.
The iliac bones were small with reduced height resulting in a crescent shape.
The femora lacked longitudinal orientation and had a stellate configuration.
The other long bones were short and bowed with metaphyseal spurs.
Very short and broad metacarpals and the proximal and distal phalanges were noted.
The skeletal changes were almost identical in both fetuses; except for some differences with regard to the degree of mineralization of ribs, pelvis and vertebrae (Fig. 3A,B).
